Uncle Blue owns the place. He's a fierce-looking man with thick black beard, powerful hands, and no tolerance for incompetence. It's hard to determine his age— anywhere fr forty to sixty. Valghobek, his lieutenant, looks at first glance like an overweight suburban dad. But on closer inspection there i something absolutely mirthless in his smile, a meanness around his eyes. dialogues.speaker: MR. BROGAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You find the right people and you get yourself papers, a driver's license. EXT. TOWN BAR — DAY Monty sits on the steps in back of the bar, looking out p the gravel lot toward the distant mountains.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROGAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And then you wait. People get caught when they come home. But you're never coming ome. EXT. BUS STATION — DAY Monty, a few years older, waits as a Greyhound bus pulls the station.

dialogues.text: And maybe-— and this is dangerous— but Maybe after a couple years you send word to Naturelle. Naturelle steps off the Greyhound bus. She sees Monty. Th stare at each other, twenty feet apart. Finally he goes to her, threading through the other -_ ; travellers, the other waiting families. He takes her in h arms. De soos INT. APARTMENT, — NIGHT oo. In the cramped apartment above the bar where Monty works, Monty and Naturelle sit together, on a sofa, watching a s television. Naturelle is pregnant. The ball is about to drop in Times Square.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROGAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You forget about New York. You can't come back. You can't call, you can't write. INT. SMALL HOUSE — NIGHT Monty, much older now, stands in front of his family, his grown CHILDREN and the little GRANDCHILDREN. Naturelle, equally aged, sits with one of the little girls on her la (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROGAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And maybe one day, years from now,. long ~ after I'm dead and gone, you gather your whole family together and you tell them the truth. Who you are and where you came rom. As Monty speaks his children exchange glances. They can't really believe what they're hearing, but they know their father is telling the truth.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You tell them the whole thing. And then you ask them if they know how lucky they are to be there. Monty looks at his family. He is awed by their existence, the life he has created. He looks at Naturelle, still beautiful in old age, and she smiles back at him. OLD MONTY . It all came so close to never happening. INT. MR. BROGAN'S HONDA — MORNING The sun shines through the windshield. Monty sleeps, his battered head resting against the window below his frost- spelt name: M-O-N-T-Y.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MONTY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This life came so close to never happening.
